channel.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
channel.description: How independent is Auxy when it comes to mixing & mastering? From my understanding we don’t have mastering features in Auxy and all of the knobs are for attaing a proper mix right? Plus I read about carving when you mix tracks- sure that can be done in automations correct by selectively reducing volume or using lowpass in certain segements? Plus how much of that is even necessary- live bands don’t carve- or do they? Rock bands didn’t master live stuff and people love that, right? When I throw my one whole Auxy WAV track of a whole musical song into Garageband how much do I need to EQ it there? Does it need an overall, echo, reverb, compression? Or can the track made in Auxy sound good enough without external intervention? Plus any Auxy specific differences from these tracks vs tracks made in other DAWs that we need to know of? I read on one of these posts something about not needing to reduce volume on each track cuz it will not clip anyway? Correct me if i’m wrong. Please let me know any info you guys have on this, I will greatky appreciate it! I just want my EP to sound as good as possible, oh gosh can’t wait for the update!

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
I’m not enough of an audiophile nor knowledgeable enough to really know lol everything I do I’m doing at 16 bit, even on desktops. I kind of remember reading I think from Blakkaz it had to do with increasing available headroom in a mix but it’s not going to change the “quality” of a track. A good mix is a good mix and a garbage mix is… well…

Read full topic

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
tornait:

I hope we can get to the point where we get that nice, DAW-level 24-bit.

fwiw… https://www.image-line.com/support/flstudio_online_manual/html/app_audio.htm

  • Bits & Hz - Research has shown that for music distribution, 16 Bit @ 44.1 kHz (CD standard) is indistinguishable from 24 Bit @ 192 kHz in a sample of over 550 listeners1. In other words, more bits and higher bit-rates are not going to improve the ‘quality’ of your tracks.

And the article cited…

Mixonline

The Emperor's New Sampling Rate

ARE CDS ACTUALLY GOOD ENOUGH?

I’d say 16-bit is more than enough, as I have hard enough time distinguishing what sounds like what already, and this article really puts a reality check on the importance of such a difference. I’m sure @blakkaz and @iammane have more experience and can better distinguish the 24-bit depth though and can share some opinions.

Read full topic

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?

item.description:
Ah, 16bit. I hope we can get to the point where we get that nice, DAW-level 24-bit.

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
You can, export > more > Export Individual Instruments.

Dumps every instrument to a single wav in a zip file. Pow pow! Not sure if Files does zip files, but AudioShare handles zip files perfectly. If you don’t have AudioShare… wtfffffff?

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Db909:

And when you start, you think you need tons of stuff.

I think this is the crux of the issue. I know I cringe when people start bringing up mixing and mastering as a way to make a crappy song good. Crappy songs are crappy songs no matter how much you massage the levels.

Not suggesting those asking are writing bad songs, but over all these years I feel like people think it’s like a magic pill or something. I agree with Nick and I agree with you. I think it really depends on what you’re doing, where you want the music to go (be played?) and a whole slew of other factors. Auxy definitely does not have any kind of “mastering” tools, and tbh, wouldn’t want it. Wouldn’t even want advanced EQ options. I work with a guy who has spent thousands recording in a studio and the album is taking forever and I’m thinking to myself “the things I do on a computer in one software package sound better”, and that’s terrifying.

I’m ranting now lol. Bottom line, I think it really all depends. To my ears, what I hear coming out of Auxy rivals the stuff I hear on say Electronica radio on Pandora. It’s all perception too, everyone is going to hear things differently.

Aight, I swear I’m done now. If you’ve stuck with me this far, thanks lol

Read full topic

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
No you didn’t offend me at all. To simplify I just think most people vastly over complicate mixing and overestimate the number and type of tools necessary to achieve desired results. I’ve been making electronic music for about 7 years, not paid for it or anything but it’s been a constant process of whittling away everything not needed. And when you start, you think you need tons of stuff. And everyone has mountains of advice on all the many many things you absolutely have to have and have to do. So I get a little frustrated when I see people recommending “more more more” as a solution to mix/audio/production issues. But it’s all good.

Read full topic

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: NickElle
item.description:
Mixing is not just volume. It’s WAY more complex than that. Auxy does not go complex at all. That’s the truth. I’m not saying what comes straight outta Auxy doesn’t sound good. The question was about mixing and mastering, which happens to be my job.

And, as far as going super in-detail, I love doing it, and other engineers love it too, but that doesn’t mean we have brag about it to you. We aren’t bragging about it to you, we are bragging about it to each other.
You don’t have to listen to us when we talk about that if you don’t like it.
So I’m sorry If I offended you, @Db909.

Read full topic

item.title: Mix/Master in Auxy?
item.dc:creator: Db909
item.description:
How is it not possible to “actually mix” in Auxy? I don’t understand this idea of there being a threshold of features and parameter control required to “properly mix” or “properly master”. You have controls over the sound you use in conjunction with one another to achieve pleasing audio. Period. And these Auxy tracks sound amazing straight from the app. Which is the entire point of Auxy. At the end of the day is it about the sound or is it about being able to wow other producers with epic tales of complicated fx chains and bus routing or how you spent hours eqing that snare drum until it was PERFECT? Not picking on you specifically don’t get me wrong, just this idea, which I’ve heard in various forms from various people all around.

Read full topic
